1. Using the `mpg` data, create boxplots of highway fuel efficiency as a function of class.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




2. Zoom into the plot with y-axis limits of 15 and 40 without altering the data.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(15, 40))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




3. Change the y-axis limits to 15 and 40 but allow the statistical transformations to change the data.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  ylim(15, 40)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: Removed 10 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_boxplot()`).
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




4. Replot #1 but using a log10 scale.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_y_log10()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




5. Replot #1 but with y-axis limits running from 0 to 50 and with labels in increments of 5 but no minor grid lines.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50), breaks = seq(0, 50, 5)) +
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank())
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




6. Replot #1 but create separate panels based on year (as rows) and cylinders (as columns) and allowing the scales to vary across rows.



::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(year), cols = vars(cyl), scale = "free")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::




7. Replot #1 and assign it to `hwy_plot` and replot a similar version with city fuel efficiency named `cty_plot`. Then combine them into a compound plot labeled as subfigures A and B and save this figure on your computer as a PNG file.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hwy_plot <- mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot()
cty_plot <- mpg |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = class, y = cty)) +
  geom_boxplot()
library(patchwork)
hwy_plot + cty_plot + plot_annotation(tag_levels = "A")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](36_axes_answers_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
